{{about|the medication used to relieve heartburn|the acid produced by ants, known in many languages as "ant acid"|Formic acid}}
[[Image:Antacid-L478.jpg|thumb|Antacid tablets]]
An '''antacid''' is a substance which [[neutralization (chemistry)|neutralizes]] [[gastric acid|stomach acidity]] and is used to relieve [[heartburn]], [[indigestion]] or an upset stomach.<ref name="Overviewcookie">{{Cite book|url=|title=Dyspepsia and Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease: Investigation and Management of Dyspepsia, Symptoms Suggestive of Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease, or Both|last=Internal Clinical Guidelines Team. (UK)|first=|date=2014|publisher=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (UK)|year=|isbn=|series=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence: Clinical Guidelines|location=London|pages=|pmid=25340236}}</ref>
==Medical uses== Antacids are available [[over the counter]] and are taken by mouth to quickly relieve occasional [[heartburn]], the major symptom of [[gastroesophageal reflux disease]] and [[indigestion]]. Treatment with antacids alone is [[Symptomatic treatment|symptomatic]] and only justified for minor symptoms.<ref name=AHRQ>U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality 23 September 2011 [http://effectivehealthcare.ahrq.gov/index.cfm/search-for-guides-reviews-and-reports/?pageaction=displayproduct&productID=756 Consumer Summary – Treatment Options for GERD or Acid Reflux Disease: A Review of the Research for Adults] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011121858/http://effectivehealthcare.ahrq.gov/index.cfm/search-for-guides-reviews-and-reports/?productid=756&pageaction=displayproduct |date=2014-10-11 }}</ref>
Antacids are distinct from acid-reducing drugs like [[H2 antagonist|H<sub>2</sub>-receptor antagonist]]s or [[proton pump inhibitor]]s and they do not kill the bacteria ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'', which causes most [[gastric ulcer|ulcers]].<ref name=AHRQ/>
Non-particulate antacids (sodium citrate, magnesium trisilicate) increase gastric pH with little or no effect on gastric volume. Sodium citrate should be given within 1 hour of surgery to be the most effective.<ref>Practice Guidelines for Preoperative Fasting and the Use of Pharmacologic Agents to Reduce the Risk of Pulmonary Aspiration: Application to Healthy Patients Undergoing Elective Procedures: An Updated Report by the American Society of Anesthesiologists Task Force on Preoperative Fasting and the Use of Pharmacologic Agents to Reduce the Risk of Pulmonary Aspiration. Anesthesiology. 2017 March; 126(3).</ref>
==Side effects== Versions with magnesium may cause diarrhea, and brands with calcium or aluminium may cause constipation and rarely, long-term use may cause kidney stones. Long-term use of versions with aluminium may increase the risk for getting [[osteoporosis]].<ref name="MedlinePlus">U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Institutes of Health, U.S. National Library of Medicine. Page last updated: 7 November 2014 [https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000198.htm Medline Plus: Taking Antacids]</ref>
==Mechanism of action== When excessive amounts of acids are produced in the stomach the natural mucous barrier that protects the lining of the stomach can damage the esophagus in people with [[Gastroesophageal reflux disease|acid reflux]]. Antacids contain [[alkaline]] ions that [[Neutralization (chemistry)|chemically neutralize]] stomach [[gastric acid]], reducing damage and relieving pain.<ref name="Overviewcookie" />
==Formulations and brands== Antacids may be formulated with other [[active pharmaceutical ingredient|active ingredients]] such as [[simethicone]] to control [[Flatulence|gas]] or [[alginic acid]] to act as a physical barrier to acid.<ref>IFFGD. [http://www.iffgd.org/site/manage-your-health/diet-treatments/antacids Antacids] Adapted from IFFGD Publication #520 by W. Grant Thompson. Last modified on 12 September 2014</ref>
===Effervescents=== Effervescent tablets are tablets which are designed to dissolve in water, and then release a level of [[carbon dioxide]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dubogrey|first1=Ilya|title=Putting the Fizz into Formulation|url=http://www.samedanltd.com/magazine/11/issue/204/article/3622|work=European Pharmaceutical Contractor|issue=Autumn|date=2013}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130103012204/http://www.newdruginfo.com/pharmacopeia/bp2003/British%20Pharmacopoeia%20Volume%20III/Monographs/Formulated%20Preparations%20Genearal%20Monographs/TABLETS.htm British Pharmacopeia 2003]</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=International Pharmacopoeia 2006|url=https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_s_sBKJNf184C|accessdate=1 July 2013|year=2006|publisher=World Health Organization|isbn=978-92-4-156301-7|pages=[https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_s_sBKJNf184C/page/n993 966]}}</ref> The common ingredients are [[citric acid]] and [[sodium bicarbonate]], which react when in contact with water to produce carbon dioxide. Effervescent antacids may also contain [[aspirin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alkaseltzer.ie/en/about-alka-seltzer/|title=Alka Seltzer Directions of use, Sodium & Aspirin content - Alka Seltzer relief from Headaches, Migraine & Upset stomach|work=alkaseltzer.ie|access-date=2017-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429145428/http://www.alkaseltzer.ie/en/about-alka-seltzer/|archive-date=2015-04-29|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[sodium carbonate]], or [[tartaric acid]].<ref name=Blair>{{cite encyclopedia | last1 = Blair | first1 = G. T. | title = Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology | last2 = DeFraties | first2 = J. J. | url = | encyclopedia = Kirk Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology | year = 2000 | issue = | pages = 1–19 | doi = 10.1002/0471238961.0825041802120109.a01 | chapter = Hydroxy Dicarboxylic Acids | isbn = 978-0471238966 }}</ref>
Well known brands are [[Alka-Seltzer]], [[Eno (drug)|Eno]] and [[Andrews (drug)|Andrews]].
===Algeldrate===
[[Image:Old aluminum tablets.JPG|160px|thumb|Wyeth amphojel tablets of aluminum hydroxide.]] Under the generic name algeldrate, [[aluminium hydroxide]] is used as an antacid. Aluminium hydroxide is preferred over other alternatives such as [[sodium bicarbonate]] because Al(OH)<sub>3</sub>, being insoluble, does not increase the pH of stomach above 7 and hence, does not trigger secretion of excess [[stomach acid]]. Brand names include Alu-Cap, Aludrox, Gaviscon, and Pepsamar. In 2016 Gaviscon was one of the biggest selling branded over-the-counter medications sold in Great Britain, with sales of £62 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=A breakdown of the over-the-counter medicines market in Britain in 2016|url=http://www.pharmaceutical-journal.com/20202662.article|accessdate=29 May 2017|publisher=Pharmaceutical Journal|date=28 April 2017}}</ref> It reacts with excess acid in the stomach, reducing the acidity of the stomach content,<ref>{{cite book |author1=Galbraith, A |author2=Bullock, S |author3=Manias, E |author4=Hunt, B. |author5=Richards, A. | year = 1999 | title = Fundamentals of pharmacology: a text for nurses and health professionals | location = Harlow | publisher = Pearson | pages = 482}}</ref> which may relieve the symptoms of ulcers, heartburn or dyspepsia. Such products can cause [[constipation]], because the aluminum ions inhibit the contractions of [[smooth muscle cells]] in the gastrointestinal tract, slowing [[peristalsis]] and lengthening the time needed for stool to pass through the colon.<ref name="Washington1991">{{cite book|last1=Washington|first1=Neena|title=Antacids and Anti Reflux Agents|date=2 August 1991|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton, FL|isbn=978-0-8493-5444-1|page=10}}</ref> Some such products are formulated to minimize such effects through the inclusion of equal concentrations of [[magnesium hydroxide]] or [[magnesium carbonate]], which have counterbalancing laxative effects.
